clusters.title: Trump threatens to block opening of Gordie Howe International Bridge
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Threatens To Block US Canada Bridge

items.title: Trump threatens to block opening of Gordie Howe International Bridge
items.standfirst: President Trump said Monday he would block the opening of the Gordie Howe International Bridge between Detroit and Canada "until the United States is fully compensated for everything we have given them."
items.content: President Trump said Monday he would block the opening of the Gordie Howe International Bridge between Detroit and Canada "until the United States is fully compensated for everything we have given them."

items.title: Trump threatens to block opening of US-Canada bridge
items.standfirst: The Gordie Howe International Bridge, which connects Michigan to Ontario, is set to open this year.
items.content: The Gordie Howe International Bridge, which connects Michigan to Ontario, is set to open this year.

items.title: Trump threatens to block opening of Ontario-Michigan bridge financed by Canada
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump has threatened to bar a new $4.7 billion bridge connecting Michigan and Ontario from opening, in his latest salvo against Canada over trade issues. Trump said the US should own "at least half" of the forthcoming Gordie Howe International Bridge that has been entirely financed by Canada.
items.content: US President Donald Trump has threatened to bar a new $4.7 billion bridge connecting Michigan and Ontario from opening, in his latest salvo against Canada over trade issues. Trump said the US should own "at least half" of the forthcoming Gordie Howe International Bridge that has been entirely financed by Canada.

items.title: Trump threatens to block opening of Detroit-Canada bridge
items.standfirst: The $4.6bn Gordie Howe International Bridge is expected to open in early 2026.
items.content: The $4.6bn Gordie Howe International Bridge is expected to open in early 2026.

items.title: Trump threatens to block new bridge in latest tirade against Canada
items.standfirst: President says Gordie Howe Bridge will open only when US is ‘fully compensated’ – and makes bizarre hockey claimAs Democrats prepare to force a vote in the US House this week on Donald Trump’s tariffs on Canada, the president posted a lengthy diatribe on his social media platform in which he threatened to block a bridge connecting the US and Canada and made a bizarre false claim that increased trade between Canada and China would include a ban on Canadians playing ice hockey.Trump began his latest screed against the US’s second-largest trading partner by claiming that “everyone knows, the Country of Canada has treated the United States very unfairly for decades”. Continue reading...
items.content: President says Gordie Howe Bridge will open only when US is ‘fully compensated’ – and makes bizarre hockey claimAs Democrats prepare to force a vote in the US House this week on Donald Trump’s tariffs on Canada, the president posted a lengthy diatribe on his social media platform in which he threatened to block a bridge connecting the US and Canada and made a bizarre false claim that increased trade between Canada and China would include a ban on Canadians playing ice hockey.Trump began his latest screed against the US’s second-largest trading partner by claiming that “everyone knows, the Country of Canada has treated the United States very unfairly for decades”. Continue reading...

items.title: Meta, Google stand trial over accusations apps designed to addict children
items.standfirst: A landmark trial began in a California court Monday in which social media giants Meta and Google-owned YouTube stand accused of designing their apps to be addictive to children. "This case is about two of the richest corporations in history who have engineered addiction in children's brains," plaintiffs' attorney Mark Lanier told the jury in his opening statement.

Also in this edition, French President Emmanuel Macron calls for the EU to launch a joint borrowing mechanism to invest in AI, green tech and quantum computing.

items.title: Jimmy Lai: will Hong Kong media tycoon die in jail? – The Latest
items.standfirst: The media mogul and prominent pro-democracy activist Jimmy Lai has been sentenced to 20 years in prison in Hong Kong for national security offences. His family has described the sentence as ‘heartbreakingly cruel’, given the 78-year-old’s declining health. Lai was convicted in December on charges of sedition and conspiracy to collude with foreign forces, after pleading not guilty to all charges. Lucy Hough speaks to the Guardian’s senior China correspondent, Amy Hawkins – watch on YouTube Continue reading...
items.content: The media mogul and prominent pro-democracy activist Jimmy Lai has been sentenced to 20 years in prison in Hong Kong for national security offences. His family has described the sentence as ‘heartbreakingly cruel’, given the 78-year-old’s declining health. Lai was convicted in December on charges of sedition and conspiracy to collude with foreign forces, after pleading not guilty to all charges. items.title: Starmer 'clinging on by his teeth' as fallout from Epstein files spreads
items.standfirst: UK premier Keir Starmer insisted he would not "walk away" on Monday after a prominent ally demanded the prime minister quit for embroiling the British government in the Jeffrey Epstein scandal. Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar called on Starmer to resign for appointing Peter Mandelson as US ambassador despite knowing he had maintained links to Epstein. But even as senior ministers rally around the beleaguered PM, it was clear Starmer is “clinging on by his teeth”, says France 24’s Philip Turle.

items.title: Federal judge blocks California from enforcing ICE mask ban
items.standfirst: Judge rules that law discriminates against federal government because it does not apply to state authoritiesA federal judge on Monday blocked a California law from going into effect that would ban federal immigration agents from covering their faces, but they will still be required to wear clear identification showing their agency and badge number.California became the first state to ban most law enforcement officers from wearing facial coverings under a bill that was signed by Gavin Newsom, the governor, in September, following last summer’s high-profile raids by ICE officers in Los Angeles. Continue reading...
items.content: Judge rules that law discriminates against federal government because it does not apply to state authoritiesA federal judge on Monday blocked a California law from going into effect that would ban federal immigration agents from covering their faces, but they will still be required to wear clear identification showing their agency and badge number.California became the first state to ban most law enforcement officers from wearing facial coverings under a bill that was signed by Gavin Newsom, the governor, in September, following last summer’s high-profile raids by ICE officers in Los Angeles. Continue reading...

items.title: Judge blocks California law banning federal law enforcement agents from wearing masks
items.standfirst: A federal judge has blocked a California law from going into effect that would ban federal immigration agents from covering their faces but they will still be required to wear clear identification showing their agency and badge number.
items.content: A federal judge has blocked a California law from going into effect that would ban federal immigration agents from covering their faces but they will still be required to wear clear identification showing their agency and badge number.

ai_summary: A federal judge blocked a California law
The law banned federal agents from wearing masks
Agents must wear clear identification
The law was signed by Governor Gavin Newsom
The judge ruled the law discriminates against the federal government

clusters.title: Catherine O'Hara's cause of death confirmed as blood clot
clusters.neutral_headline: Catherine OHara Cause Of Death Confirmed

items.title: Catherine O'Hara's cause of death confirmed as blood clot
items.standfirst: The Schitt's Creek and Home Alone actress died last month in a US hospital, at the age of 71.
items.content: The Schitt's Creek and Home Alone actress died last month in a US hospital, at the age of 71.

items.title: Catherine O'Hara's cause of death was a pulmonary embolism
items.standfirst: Catherine O'Hara, known for her roles in "Home Alone," "Schitt's Creek" and "Beetlejuice," died on Jan. 30 at the age of 71.
items.content: Catherine O'Hara, known for her roles in "Home Alone," "Schitt's Creek" and "Beetlejuice," died on Jan. 30 at the age of 71.

ai_summary: Catherine OHara died at the age of 71
The cause of death was a pulmonary embolism
She died in a US hospital last month
OHara was known for her roles in Home Alone
She also appeared in Schitts Creek and Beetlejuice
